ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A look into what it's like to work at the state department/any government agency - very unique assignments and assessments

I learned many basic skills of professional competency, like how to write an effective memo, or how to summarize a conversation efficiently. But I also learned many life lessons from Professor Rank's lifetime in service, like how to work with a boss, how to be a good colleague, and how to be a good leader.

This course really teaches you how to write a memo. Prof. Rank will give incredibly detailed (and mildly esoteric) feedback on all of your work and spends 15-20 minutes of each class period laying out his writing advice. My work became much more specific, deliberate, and concise throughout the semester and I appreciate that. 

You also gain a pretty thorough understanding of the tensions that have driven conflict on the Korean Peninsula from WWII to now. There will likely be a DPRK crisis in your semester! You will learn about that.

Learned about the history of the Korean peninsula crisis and the major players. We spent a lot of the time developing memo-writing skills designed to prepare you to actually work in the policy process.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Rank is THE BEST! I learned so much from this class because of his guidance.
This is an excellent course. I think there is little room for improvement.

Classes were great, topics were engaging, and discussions were lively. Readings were manageable and interesting. I liked the assignment structure -- a lot of little assignments rather than anything of very heavy weight. I don't really have any substantive suggestions for how it could be improved.

Strengths: feedback on writing is second-to-none and very helpful, class-led discussion is great, and simulations were very enjoyable.
Weaknesses: readings sometimes felt excessive and beyond what we discussed in class

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. One of the best GLBL seminars I've taken, and completely different from any other. Professor Rank did an amazing job of facilitating discussions and getting students to learn. Highly recommend.

Absolutely! If you want a classroom experience that facilitates real-world diplomacy and policy-making, this is the class for you. Rank's top priority is making sure you leave with a new set of hard skills. I'm so thankful that I used my last GLBL credit on this!

Yes, 100%. This course was like a crash-course in not just diplomacy, but also basic professional competency. I learned so much from Professor Rank's insights on professional life, conflict resolution, and his modeling for us, by his example, what excellent leadership looks like.
I would but I don't think it will be offered again for a while so I won't wax poetic as to why.

Yes, it's a very good class. You will get more feedback on your writing than in probably any other class and learn real practical skills. The simulations are a lot of fun, and Professor Rank tends to cultivate a great class culture.

extras.title: GLBL 355 01 - USA, China, and Korean Crisis
